_header: Think man whereof thou art wrought
_description: A mystical poem — seven l0-line stanzas with an ‘O and I’ refrain

BodDonC13.First Lines:
Think man whar to þou ert wroȝt þat is sa wlonk in
                    wedethink hou þou was hidir broȝt & of þin end take
                    hede…
BodDonC13.Last Lines:
…With an o and an I do as I þe lereIf ȝou wil
                    þat solace se þat seyntis syttis sere

CULGg132.First Lines:
Thynk man qware off thou art wroughtþat art so wlonk in
                    wadeThynk hou þu art hedyr bought& of thyn end take
                    hede…
CULGg132.Last Lines:
…With an O and an I thynk qwat I ye lereIff þu wil
                    þat solace se þer seyntis syttes sere
CULGg132.Editions:
Brunner,  Karl. 
             “With an O and an J. I.” 
             Anglia
         54 (1930): 288-91: 290-1.
Greene,  Richard Leighton. 
             The Early English Carols.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1935; 2nd ed., rev., Oxford: Clarendon,
            1977: 422; 1977, 439 (first four lines only).
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild,
                        ed.  
             Religious Lyrics of the XVth Century.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1939: 256-8.
